lip
old variant of 亡[wang2]
to die/to lose/to be gone/to flee/deceased

definition: lit. as close as lips and teeth (idiom); closely related/interdependent
precarious as pile of eggs (idiom); ready to fall and break at any moment/in a dangerous state
if two tigers fight, one will get injured (idiom)/if you start a war, someone is bound to get hurt

definition: lit. sandpiper and clam war together and the fisherman catches both (idiom); fig. neighbors who can't agree lose out to a third party

definition: two tigers fighting (idiom); fierce contest between evenly matched adversaries
to form an alliance/to ally oneself with/allied with/aligned/to bond with
It's hard to clap with only one hand./It takes two to tango/It's difficult to achieve anything without support.
lit. to nurture a tiger invites calamity/fig. to indulge one's enemy is asking for trouble (idiom)

a fire in the city gates is also a calamity for the fish in the moat (idiom); the bystander will also suffer/fig. you can't escape responsibility for your actions/ask not for whom the bell tolls - it tolls for thee
pinyin: cheng2 men2 shi1 huo3 , yang1 ji2 chi2 yu2

definition: a centipede dies but never falls down/old institutions die hard

definition: anger against a common enemy (idiom); joined in opposition to the same adversary
ambition of wild wolves (idiom); rapacious designs
to loot a burning house/to profit from sb's misfortune (idiom)
lit. the birds are over, the bow is put away (idiom); fig. to get rid of sb once he has served his purpose
to meet on the battlefield (idiom)
